edu.columbia.cs.sdarts.util
Class XMLWriter

java.lang.Object
  |
  +--java.io.Writer
        |
        +--java.io.PrintWriter
              |
              +--edu.columbia.cs.sdarts.util.XMLWriter
public class XMLWriter
extends java.io.PrintWriter

A specialized java.io.PrintWriter designed specifically for outputting XML.

The first output from the writer will usually be a standard XML declaration, including <?XML ...> and <!DOCTYPE . . . >. The <!DOCTYPE . . . > will include the main DTD for the document, and will even include external parameter entities. The XMLWriter learns about DOCTYPES statically, using the addPublicDocType() and addSystemDocType() methods, which correspond to the PUBLIC and SYSTEM XML DOCTYPES. Since these methods are static, they need be called only once for each DOCTYPE added.

There are also plenty of convenience methods for outputting all XML structures, as well as strict control over indenting and carriage returns. The XMLWriter keeps track of depth of indentation, and whether it is in a particular namespace or not, and outputs accordingly. There are methods to control these properties, as well.

XMLWriter

public XMLWriter(java.io.OutputStream out)
Create an XMLWriter that DOES NOT output a standard XML declaration header.
Parameters:
out - the OutputStream to wrap the XMLWriter around.

XMLWriter

public XMLWriter(java.io.OutputStream out,
                 java.lang.String[] docTypes)
          throws java.io.IOException
Create an XMLWriter that outputs a standard XML declaration header, including a <!DOCTYPE . . . > header. The XMLWriter must be pre-informed, via the static setPublicDocType() and setSystemDocType() methods, about all DOCTYPES passed in as parameters.

If there is more than one DOCTYPE in the parameter array, the first one will be declared the DOCTYPE, and the others will be declared as external parameter entities. This is the way, for example, that STARTS gets nested within SDLIP.

Note that the autoFlush property of the PrintWriter superclass is set to false

Parameters:
out - the OutputStream to wrap the XMLWriter around.
docTypes - the DOCTYPES used in the resulting document

XMLWriter

public XMLWriter(java.io.OutputStream out,
                 boolean autoFlush,
                 java.lang.String[] docTypes)
          throws java.io.IOException
Create an XMLWriter that outputs a standard XML declaration header, including a <!DOCTYPE . . . > header. The XMLWriter must be pre-informed, via the static setPublicDocType() and setSystemDocType() methods, about all DOCTYPES passed in as parameters.

If there is more than one DOCTYPE in the parameter array, the first one will be declared the DOCTYPE, and the others will be declared as external parameter entities. This is the way, for example, that STARTS gets nested within SDLIP.

Parameters:
out - the OutputStream to wrap the XMLWriter around.
autoFlush - whether the underlying stream automatically flushes or not
docTypes - the DOCTYPES used in the resulting document

XMLWriter

public XMLWriter(java.io.OutputStream out,
                 boolean autoFlush,
                 boolean autoIndent,
                 boolean autoCR,
                 boolean isolateAttributes,
                 java.lang.String[] docTypes)
          throws java.io.IOException
Create an XMLWriter that outputs a standard XML declaration header, including a <!DOCTYPE . . . > header. The XMLWriter must be pre-informed, via the static setPublicDocType() and setSystemDocType() methods, about all DOCTYPES passed in as parameters.

If there is more than one DOCTYPE in the parameter array, the first one will be declared the DOCTYPE, and the others will be declared as external parameter entities. This is the way, for example, that STARTS gets nested within SDLIP.

Parameters:
out - the OutputStream to wrap the XMLWriter around.
autoFlush - whether the underlying stream automatically flushes or not
autoIndent - whether to automatically indent each element
autoCR - whether to automatically emit a carriage return after each element or value
isolateAttributes - whether each attribute of a printed XML element should be on its own line (good for elements with lots of attributes)
docTypes - the DOCTYPES used in the resulting document

XMLWriter

public XMLWriter(java.io.Writer out,
                 java.lang.String[] docTypes)
          throws java.io.IOException
Create an XMLWriter that outputs a standard XML declaration header, including a <!DOCTYPE . . . > header. The XMLWriter must be pre-informed, via the static setPublicDocType() and setSystemDocType() methods, about all DOCTYPES passed in as parameters.

If there is more than one DOCTYPE in the parameter array, the first one will be declared the DOCTYPE, and the others will be declared as external parameter entities. This is the way, for example, that STARTS gets nested within SDLIP.

Note that the autoFlush property of the PrintWriter superclass is set to false

Parameters:
out - the Writer to wrap the XMLWriter around.
docTypes - the DOCTYPES used in the resulting document

XMLWriter

public XMLWriter(java.io.Writer out,
                 boolean autoFlush,
                 boolean autoIndent,
                 boolean autoCR,
                 boolean isolateAttributes,
                 java.lang.String[] docTypes)
          throws java.io.IOException
Create an XMLWriter that outputs a standard XML declaration header, including a <!DOCTYPE . . . > header. The XMLWriter must be pre-informed, via the static setPublicDocType() and setSystemDocType() methods, about all DOCTYPES passed in as parameters.

If there is more than one DOCTYPE in the parameter array, the first one will be declared the DOCTYPE, and the others will be declared as external parameter entities. This is the way, for example, that STARTS gets nested within SDLIP.

Parameters:
out - the Writer to wrap the XMLWriter around.
autoFlush - whether the underlying stream automatically flushes or not
autoIndent - whether to automatically indent each element
autoCR - whether to automatically emit a carriage return after each element or value
isolateAttributes - whether each attribute of a printed XML element should be on its own line (good for elements with lots of attributes)
docTypes - the DOCTYPES used in the resulting document
Method Detail

indent

public void indent()
Increase the indentation of the next XML element by one tab. If the autoIndent property is true, this indentation will be printed before each element and value

unindent

public void unindent()
Decrease the indentation of the next XML element by one tab If the autoIndent property is true, this indentation will be printed before each element and value

enterNamespace

public void enterNamespace(java.lang.String namespace)
Indicate that all future elements will have the given namespace. XMLWriter stores invocations of this method on a stack, so that it is possible to return to a previously-entered namespace using the exitNamespace() method. NOTE:XMLWriter does not assign namespaces to attributes, as this is considered tedious.
Parameters:
namespace - the new namespace for future output

exitNamespace

public void exitNamespace()
Return the XMLWriter to the namespace entered during the previous invocation of enterNamespace(), or to no namespace if there wasn't one.

clearNamespaces

public void clearNamespaces()
Forget the history of all namespaces entered, and return to the default namespace.

setAutoIndent

public void setAutoIndent(boolean autoIndent)
Tell XMLWriter whether to indent each element and value it outputs. The size of this indentation is controlled by the indent() and unindent() methods.
Parameters:
autoIndent - whether to automatically indent or not

setAutoCR

public void setAutoCR(boolean autoCR)
Tell XMLWriter whether to emit a carriage return after each element and value it outputs
Parameters:
autoCR - whether to emit a carriage return after each element and value outputted

setIsolateAttributes

public void setIsolateAttributes(boolean isolateAttributes)
Tell XMLWriter whether each attribute in a tag it prints should appear on its own line, or not (good for large bunches of attributes)
Parameters:
isolateAttributes - whether or not each attribute gets its own line

setDefaultFormat

public void setDefaultFormat()
Sets XMLWriter to a state where the autoIndent property is true, autoCR is true, and isolateAttributes is false.

printEntireElement

public void printEntireElement(java.lang.String name,
                               java.lang.String value)
                        throws java.io.IOException
Prints an entire XML element (opening tag, value, and closing tag) all on one line. Such an element has no attributes.
Parameters:
name - the name of the element
value - the value of the element

printEntireElement

public void printEntireElement(java.lang.String name,
                               java.lang.String value,
                               boolean onOneLine)
                        throws java.io.IOException
Prints an entire XML element (opening tag, value, and closing tag). Such an element has no attributes.
Parameters:
name - the name of the element
value - the value of the element
onOneLine - whether the element should appear all on one line, or just following whatever state the autoCR property is in

printStartElement

public void printStartElement(java.lang.String name)
                       throws java.io.IOException
Print only the starting part of an XML element
Example: < element>
Parameters:
name - the name of the element

printStartElement

public void printStartElement(java.lang.String name,
                              boolean hasAttributes)
                       throws java.io.IOException
Print only the starting part of an XML element, and say whether or not this element has attributes. If it does not, it will appear as:
< element>
If it does, it will appear as < element
thus leaving a place for the attributes
Parameters:
name - the name of the element
hasAttributes - whether this element has attributes

printValue

public void printValue(java.lang.String value)
                throws java.io.IOException
Print only the value from inside an element
Parameters:
value - the value

printStartElementClose

public void printStartElementClose()
                            throws java.io.IOException
Prints the character: >. Used after several attributes have been printed in a starting element. A common mistake is to forget calling this method after printing attributes!

printEndElement

public void printEndElement(java.lang.String name)
                     throws java.io.IOException
Prints the ending part of the element.
Example:
< /element>
Parameters:
name - the name of the element

printEmptyElement

public void printEmptyElement(java.lang.String name)
                       throws java.io.IOException
Prints an element that has no attributes or values.
Example:
< element/>
Parameters:
name - the name of the element

printEmptyElementClose

public void printEmptyElementClose()
                            throws java.io.IOException
Prints the following: />. Useful for closing an element that has attributes but no value. A common mistake is to forget to call this after printing attributes!
